hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Leah broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{1}5&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{5}8}&\\
\goldE{500}&\quad \goldE{50} \times \goldE{10}
\end{align}$

There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there is $1$ ten in $15$.  Also,
$\goldE{50}\times\goldE{10}=\goldE{500}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
1\maroonE{5}&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE{5}8}&\\
500&\quad 50 \times 10\\
\maroonE{250}&\quad \maroonE{50} \times \maroonE{5}
\end{align}$

There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there are $5$ ones in $15$.  Also,
$\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{250}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
\tealE{1}5&\\
\underline{{} \times 5\tealE{8}}&\\
500&\quad 50 \times 10 \\
250&\quad 50 \times 5 \\
\tealE{80}&\quad \tealE{8} \times \tealE{10}
\end{align}$

Leah said that $\tealE{8}\times\tealE{10}$ equals $800$, so Leah made a mistake in step $3$.
Leah made a mistake in step $3$.

question.content:
Leah tried to evaluate $15\times58$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&15 \\
&&\underline{{}\times58} \\
&\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{500}& \goldE{50\times 10}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{250}& \maroonE{50\times 5}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{800}& \tealE{8\times 10}\\
&\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{40}}& \blueE{8\times5}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{1{,}590}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Leah's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there is $1$ ten in $15$.  Also,
$\goldE{50}\times\goldE{10}=\goldE{500}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $1$.

There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there are $5$ ones in $15$.  Also,
$\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{250}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $2$.
$\tealE{8}\times\tealE{10}=80$, not $800$. So Leah made a mistake in step $3$.

There are $8$ ones in $58$, and there are $5$ ones in $15$.  Also,
$\blueE{8}\times\blueE{5}=\blueE{40}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $4$.
Leah correctly added her four partial products.
